> It's weird that we accept Strings, but not small Longs if the type is `Int`

@ijuma Not sure I totally agree. I think we get into annoyingly complex and dangerous territory if we accept arbitrary conversions. String conversions are basically required because we need to accept configs from properties files/connect configurations/etc. Other numeric coercion isn't strictly required, and gets annoying complex. And most errors are caught trivially (e.g., forget to put an `L` on that long? Any trivial test will catch it for you).

In general, I think we should shy away from trying to rectify the types of arbitrary `Map<String, ?>` configs -- I understand why that type was used, but it creates a huge parsing/conversion mess.

Since this PR was more about the unclear error messages, I'd suggest merging as is (perhaps with a clarification re: shorts, which I agree may not be accessible to all audiences that may want to use Kafka) and addressing any further refinements in parsing/conversion in a follow up JIRA.

One more general comment:

This RS raised the thought, that our standby task configuration is rather "all or nothing". Do you think it would make sense to allow a more fine grained configuration? I.e., allow to specify the number of standby replicas individually for each stateful operator?

Furthermore: if I understand the PR correctly, we create standby task even for stateless tasks -- thats seems to be rather odd (even if not necessarily harmful).

@ewencp, if my suggestion is controversial we can leave that for another PR and focus on the improved error messages in this one. I am OK with merging it after the clarifications for people setting these values via Kafka configs that are not necessarily Java developers.

I disagree that the conversions are complex and dangerous though (at least no more dangerous than converting from String). The only reason we're probably having this conversation is the bizarre behaviour of the `Number` conversion methods (who thought it was a good idea to overflow silently?!). Anyway, a conversation for another JIRA or PR.

@guozhangwang - interesting question. Maybe this should be something that is configurable? I'm not 100% sure, but i'm not a big fan of silently dropping the messages (even if they are recorded via metrics). The null keys could indicate problems with upstream producers - surely someone wants to know there are issues? For some apps users wont care and will be happy to drop the records, for others it might be important to stop processing.

@hachikuji, sorry for the delay. I agree that this _should_ have been the correct behaviour for the configuration. However, the previous behaviour was specified and it was not an accident either (Jun and Neha discussed it in the original JIRA). Given that and the potential impact on new deployments, a KIP seems inevitable. It should be a simple one and it will hopefully pass as easily as the unclean leader election one. :)
Sorry for the delay, I'll review this tomorrow.

No worries, I had to update grabConsoleOutput() to use the new Scala API.
The JDK7 test failure seems unrelated.

For 1, I think we all agree that it should be solved with GROUP_COORDINATOR_NOT_AVAILABLE.

For 2, I think we want to preserve existing MetadataRequest topic creation behavior by returning INVALID_REPLICATION_FACTOR, but I don't know if we actually agreed on that. If this is what we want, then I need to revise the code.
@dguy Replied to your comments. But since you opted to "request changes" I'd try to confirm if you are +1 for merging it or not.

ping @xvrl @norwood to take a look as it is slightly modifying the `StreamsMetrics` apis.

Thanks for your feedbacks @enothereska @dguy , how about fire-and-update then: accepting this change with the java doc API change indicating null-keys will be ignored if they are not mentioned yet; file another JIRA for metrics as a follow-up. And then see how user's like it or complain about it.

@jeyhunkarimov Could you make a pass over `KStream` and `KTable` interface and see if the involved functions as already indicate that null-keyed records will be dropped? If not please update them accordingly.

> You mean "runtime should not have any idea"?
Yes.

> One thing worth considering though, is that today we have seen some users using addProcessor and KStream/KTable interleavingly with KStreamBuilder. Honestly I think this is not a good pattern but would like to have us think what would potentially be restricted if we do not let KStreamBuilder to extend from TopologyBuilder anymore.

Agreed. But there should not be any limitations as we offer `KStream#transform()` that should offer all flexibility `addProcessor` offers, too. (If I don't miss anything.)

@guozhangwang Sure. 
Please assign the follow-up JIRA to me.

Any thought about this:

> This RS raised the thought, that our standby task configuration is rather "all or nothing". Do you think it would make sense to allow a more fine grained configuration? I.e., allow to specify the number of standby replicas individually for each stateful operator?

> However, this till won't work with 0.10.1+ client and 0.10.0 broker if any window operations are added. Well, this isn't testing that case. Do you think we should add that to this test? Do it as a different PR?

We fail for `0.10.0` brokers anyway because we want to drop ZK dependency. Thus, the missing `compaction+retention` feature for `0.10.0` is no issues as we do not need to add a test for it. Do we?
I updated the PR assuming the behavior mentioned in my previous comment.

All jenkins timeout are on the same test case:

```

org.apache.kafka.streams.KafkaStreamsTest > testCannotStartTwice STARTED
Build timed out (after 180 minutes). Marking the build as aborted.
```

> Any thought about this:

It is an interesting question. Today num.replicas is on tasks, which is abstracted away for end users; so as you mentioned if we want to be user-customizable finer-grained then it needs to be per-operator, which I feel would be quite tricky for users to understand / specify.

> Any thoughts about this @dguy @guozhangwang -- this is a different issues than the newly created JIRA (even if we might be able to subsume it with it). The issue described here would also be there, if we only assign stateful standby tasks.

I think I agree. It seems that once all clients are over capacity then we just treat them equally when assigning (assuming no prev standby / active tasks considered). It seems better to assign the tasks to over-capacity clients also to be depending on their total capacity. For example, if client1 has cap. 1, client2 has cap. 2, and we have a total of 6 tasks, it would be better to assign them as 2 : 4 to these two clients than 3 : 3?

Refer to this link for build results (access rights to CI server needed): 
https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-pr-jdk7-scala2.10/1193/
Test FAILed (JDK 7 and Scala 2.10).

About fine grained configuration:
Yes, users should not need to think about tasks. It should be on operator basis. Thus, we would need to make standby tasks "smarter" and only populate some stores (as requested by the user) in the background. Would be a bigger change, but not impossible.

> For example, if client1 has cap. 1, client2 has cap. 2, and we have a total of 6 tasks, it would be better to assign them as 2 : 4 to these two clients than 3 : 3?

Yes, that is exactly what I had in mind.

@guozhangwang Just to be sure, did you mean checking only join related APIs of `KStream/KTable` or all applicable APIs? So, are we going to treat `drop-null `behaviour to all APIs? For example, I see that flatmap (`KStreamFlatMapProcessor`) does not check for `null`. So, if we try to behave similar (avoid `null` keys) in all `Processors` I think we should avoid code replication.
@jeyhunkarimov Let's not keep enlarging the scope of this PR, and only restrict to joins.

https://builds.apache.org/job/kafka-pr-jdk7-scala2.10/1193/testReport/junit/org.apache.kafka.streams.integration/QueryableStateIntegrationTest/queryOnRebalance_0_/

Is this related to the change or maybe an existing issue that is not fixed yet?
